moves.1. e4: Standard king's pawn. As white, I never play this, ever.
moves.1... d5: Scandinavian. This is fun and exciting, but if white plays 2. e5, it becomes annoying to knock out the pawn.
moves.2... Nc6: Standard development. 2. e5 e3 would also work.
moves.3. f4: (?) Why not d4? 3. f4 weakens the kingside.
moves.3... e6 4. Bb5: Pinning the knight to the king, as well as developing the kingside.
moves.4... Bd7 5. c3: (!) Plans to play d4, creating a pawn chain, and aiming for Qa4.
moves.5... Bc5: This frees up e7 for the knight, attacks f2, and develops the bishop.
moves.6. b4: (?) d4 would have been better, as it blocks the a7-g1 diagonal, and creates a pawn chain.
moves.6... Bb6: Running back to e7 would be pointless, so Bb6 is my only option.
moves.7. d4 Nge7: Developing the knight, and getting ready to castle.
moves.8. Qg4: (!) Obviously, the queenside is a wreck, and so white moves the queen to a strong position.
moves.8... Ng6: This prevents any attempts for checkmate later in the game, opens the queen diagonal, and strengthens the kingside.
moves.9. Nf3: The kingside is now safe, so white seizes the opportunity to castle.
moves.9... O-O 10. Nh4: (?) This is basically giving black a knight.
moves.12... Nxg2+ 13. Kf2 Nxf4: Remember the old adage, eat a pawn chain from the back.
moves.15... a6: (!) A6 both rids the white bishop, and provides an escape route for the bishop.
moves.16. Bd3: (?) White should have traded bishops. The black bishop on d7 is basically trapped, and white could move the dark bishop out, and it creates triple pawns for black.
moves.17. Kg4 Ng2: (?) The black knight is trapped. Nf5 or Ng6 would be better.
moves.19. Kxh5 g6+: I made this move to lure the king closer. Flip the board and see how crowded black is.
moves.21. Rg1: Attacks the knight, and after taking the knight, pinning the pawn. I can't move Nf4 or Nh4, because if the pin.
moves.21... f6: I made this move to chip away at white's pawn chain.
moves.22. Rxg2 fxe5 23. Rxg5+: And takes with a check. Though behind in material, white has the upper hand in position.
moves.24... Nxe5 25. Rxe5 Rf3: (!) Attacks the bishop and the h3 square.
moves.26. Bh7: (?) Re3 would be better. This loses to 26. ... Rh3+ 27. Rh5 Rxh5 28. Kxh5 Kxh7.
moves.26... Rxc3: (?) I didn't see the earlier move while I was playing.
moves.27... Rh3+ 28. Rh5 Rxh5+ 29. Kxh5 Kxh7 3: I saw a potential trap. Do you see it?
moves.31... Be8+ 32. Kh4 Bd8+: (?) I should have took the bishop.
moves.33. Bg5 Bxg5+ 34. Rxg5 cxb4: Is this the correct move, or would cxd be better? Please comment.
moves.35... b5: This is to open up the a file.
moves.38... Bxb1: And now white resigns. Promotion is inevitable, and white's pawns are scattered.
